statement:
Waring asked whether it is possible to represent every natural number as
a sum of number of nonnegative $k$’th powers, that is, whether the set
$\{\,n^k \mid n \in \mathbb{Z_+}\,\}$ is an . He was led to this
conjecture by which asserted that every natural number can be
represented as a sum of four squares.

Hilbert [@cite:hilbert_waring] was the first to prove the conjecture for
all $k$. In his paper he did not give an explicit bound on $g(k)$, the
number of powers needed, but later it was proved that
$$g(k)=2^k+\left\lfloor\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^k\right\rfloor-2$$
except possibly finitely many exceptional $k$, none of which are known.

Wooley[@cite:wooley_waring], improving the result of
Vinogradov[@cite:vinogradov_waringG], proved that the number of $k$’th
powers needed to represent all *sufficiently large* integers is
$$G(k)\leq k (\ln k + \ln \ln k + O(1)).$$
